title: Famous Diplomats Quiz
description: How well do you recall the diplomats who shaped international relations?

questions.question: Which diplomat served as US Secretary of State and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the end of the Vietnam War?
questions.explanation: Henry Kissinger won the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the Paris Peace Accords that ended US involvement in the Vietnam War.

questions.question: Which diplomat helped create the United Nations and served as its first Secretary-General?
questions.explanation: Trygve Lie of Norway served as the first Secretary-General of the United Nations from 1946 to 1952.

questions.question: Which Austrian diplomat organized the Congress of Vienna after Napoleon's defeat?
questions.explanation: Prince Klemens von Metternich hosted and dominated the Congress of Vienna (1814-1815), which redesigned Europe's political map after the Napoleonic Wars.

questions.question: Which American diplomat developed the 'containment' policy against Soviet expansion?
questions.explanation: George Kennan articulated the containment policy in his famous 1947 'Long Telegram' and X Article, shaping US Cold War strategy for decades.

questions.question: Which South African leader negotiated the end of apartheid and became the country's first Black president?
questions.explanation: Nelson Mandela negotiated with President F.W. de Klerk to end apartheid and became South Africa's first Black president in 1994.

questions.question: Which US diplomat created the Marshall Plan to rebuild post-WWII Europe?
questions.explanation: Secretary of State George C. Marshall proposed the European Recovery Program (Marshall Plan) in 1947, winning the Nobel Peace Prize in 1953.

questions.question: Which Egyptian president signed the Camp David Accords with Israel in 1978?
questions.explanation: Anwar Sadat signed the Camp David Accords with Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin in 1978, mediated by President Jimmy Carter.

questions.question: Which UN Secretary-General died in a mysterious plane crash in Africa in 1961?
questions.explanation: Dag Hammarskjöld, the second UN Secretary-General, died in a plane crash in Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) on September 18, 1961.

questions.question: Which French diplomat represented France at the Congress of Vienna despite France having lost the Napoleonic Wars?
questions.explanation: Charles Maurice de Talleyrand skillfully represented France at the Congress of Vienna and managed to protect French interests despite being on the losing side.

questions.question: Which diplomat was known as the architect of German unification in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: Otto von Bismarck, the 'Iron Chancellor,' used diplomacy and warfare to unite the German states into the German Empire in 1871.

questions.question: Which American president brokered the Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel?
questions.explanation: President Jimmy Carter mediated the 1978 Camp David Accords between Egyptian President Anwar Sadat and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

questions.question: Which US First Lady served as a delegate to the United Nations and helped draft the Universal Declaration of Human Rights?
questions.explanation: Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the UN committee that drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted in 1948.

questions.question: Which diplomat's 'shuttle diplomacy' helped negotiate a ceasefire in the 1973 Arab-Israeli War?
questions.explanation: Henry Kissinger pioneered 'shuttle diplomacy,' traveling between Middle Eastern capitals to negotiate a ceasefire and disengagement agreements after the 1973 Yom Kippur War.

questions.question: Which Ghanaian diplomat served as UN Secretary-General and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2001?
questions.explanation: Kofi Annan of Ghana served as UN Secretary-General from 1997 to 2006 and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2001.

questions.question: Which American president proposed the 'Fourteen Points' as a basis for peace after World War I?
questions.explanation: President Woodrow Wilson presented his Fourteen Points to Congress in January 1918, outlining principles for peace including the creation of the League of Nations.
